head.title: The Sword. To Sir James Campbell, Bart.1, 1 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 33-34.22 Sir James Campbell (1679-1756), fifth baronet of Auchinbreck, began his parliamentary career in 1703 in the retinue of the house of Argyll, eventually serving as one of the Scottish representatives sent to the first Parliament of Great Britain in 1707.

lg.l: Sir, though I’m not an Antiquarian,
I’m not a tasteless rude Barbarian,
Who, without pleasure, can behold
The venerable works of old;—
’Tis true, I would not plague my noddle33 n. head.

About a rusty useless bodle;44 n. copper coin equivalent to one sixth of an English penny. Cf. Turnbull’s “A Legacy” in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 24, 1796), lines 9-10: “Imprimis—May I lose my noddle, / If I’m possessed of e’er a bodle”.
Or pay good sterling coin to gather
A purse of pieces made of leather:
Yet, when I see things worth attention,
I’d gladly ply my whole invention.

When I behold your good Claymore,55 Two-handed broad-bladed longsword used from the 15th to the 17th centuries; after the Acts of Union in 1707, claymore began to refer to basket-hilted swords, carried by Scottish officers, unlike their English counterparts who carried more slender sabers.
That erst some gallant Chieftain wore,
O ! how imagination fires
My blood, and martial thought inspires!
My view is retrospective cast,
I seem to live in ages past,
When ev’ry sire could see his son
Enlarge the conquests he had won;
When Rome’s astonish’d chiefs beheld
Her legions by our arms repel’d;66 In 411 AD, Roman legions controlling tribes north of Hadrian’s Wall broke down and were forced to depart after repeated attacks by the Picts.
And trembling senate heard afar
The dire effects of Scottish war!
Ev’n now, methinks, I see the field
Where some of our brave race did wield
This ample blade, and reeking bore
The point triumphant dy’d in gore.
I hear the noise of battle bray,
And all the horrors of the fray;
I hear the hissing javlins sing,
I hear the brazen helmts ring,
I see the vanquish’d armies fly,
I see the slaughter’d warriors ly;

And Campbells,77 Campbell clan of Auchinbreck founded by Duncan Campbell in Argyllshire. In 1628 the then head of the family received a baronetcy. Additionally, the Auchinbrecks were hereditary Lieutenant Colonels in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries and thus responsible for raising an army for the Duke of Argyll, engaging in battle such as the Monmouth Rebellion of 1685. conqu’ring, bear away
The spoils and glory of the day!
